_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Terpene Resins Process is covered under OSHA Process Safety Management regulations (29 CFR 1910.119. To be compliant with the PSM regulations and the EPA's RMP rule  Pinova,Inc. has implemented several layers of protection to prevent releases.



The first level of protection begins at the design stage. best engineering practices are used when designing new systems of modifying existing process. In addition, automatic shut-off devices as well as back up manual devices are designed into the process to reduce the likelihood of even a small leak or release.



The second layer of protection involves on-going maintenance  and up-keep of the facilities and processes. Critical equipment (including tanks, vessels, piping, relief valves, instruments, etc.) are regularly inspected and tested to ensure safe operation. 



The third layer of protection involves the safe operation of the processes. All operation and maintenance personnel receive training and certification on the equipment, chemicals, and processes with which they are involved. A permit system is in place to control access and maintenance work in and around areas containing hazardous materials. These permits require special checks and signature of plant management before personnel access or maintenance can be performed in these areas.



The final layer of protection involves auditing the operations. Routine internal audits performed by Pinova personnel are conducted to verify that the processes are safe and environmentally sound. In addition, external audits by third parties such as our customers, insurance underwriters, and various regulatory agencies are conducted periodically.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



Facility Description:



Pinova Inc. is nearly the only one of its kind in the world today that transforms abandoned pine stumps into industrial chemicals ultimately used in hundreds of consumer products, such as adhesives, sealant, chewing gum, toothpaste, citrus drinks, cleansers, and many other goods.



In making these products, the facility uses and stores (2) chemicals subject to the EPA's Risk Management Program Rule.  These chemicals are hydrogen and trimethylchlorosilane.   Hydrogen is used to hydrogenate (add hydrogen atoms to) the resins extracted from the pine stumps.  Trimethylchlorosilane is used as a processing aid in the production of polymeric terpene resins.



Hydrogen is stored in a bulk storage tank with a maximum capacity of 12,400 pounds.  This tank is owned and maintained by Air Products Corporation but is located on Pinova property.  



Trimethylchlorosilane (TMCS) is handled in portable containers weighting 725 pounds.  While the number of TMCS containers onsite may vary at any one time, with the maximum number of containers exceeding the RMP threshold quantities, only one container is connected to the process at a time.



Policy:



The Corporate Policy on Safety, Health and Environment states:



At the Pinova facility, we manufacture chemical specialty products.  We do so with full commitment to the chemical industry's Responsible Care initiative.  In keeping with this commitment, we are dedicated to providing a safe and healthful environment for our employees, customers, and communities.  To do this, we are dedicated to and working toward continuous improvement in our operations to prevent pollution; to reduce risk; and to enhance safety, health, and environmental performance.  By incorporating these beliefs and attitudes into the way we do things at Pinova, we take a key step forward in minimizing the environmental impact of our operations, satisfying customer needs, and creating shareholder value.



We will adh

ere to the following basic principles in managing our business worldwide:



-We will comply with the letter and spirit of all applicable safety, health, and environmental laws, regulations, and corporate guidelines.



-We will define strategic objectives, develop tactical plans, identify clear accountability, provide necessary resources, and measure our progress on safety, health, and environmental matters on an ongoing basis.  Our planning will consider both business goals and significant safety, health, and environmental aspects of our products and operations.



-We will evaluate the safety, health, and environmental impacts of new and existing products and operations and will work to reduce the adverse impacts. 



-We will provide for an open dialogue on safety, health, and environmental issues relating to our products and operations with our stakeholders, including shareholders, employees, customer, suppliers, government agencies, and communities.



-We will work to continually reduce workplace injuries; incidents with the potential for causing property damage, material loss, or interruption of our business; waste; and releases to the environment.



-We will promote product stewardship and advocate its importance to our suppliers, distributors, and customers.



Every employee has a role to play.  All of us are responsible and accountable for adhering to the letter and spirit of this policy.  All of us must incorporate safety, health, and environmental considerations into our daily business activities.  It takes a total team effort to truly be a Responsible Care company.



Worst-Case Scenarios:



Following the process detailed in the EPA's Off-Site Consequence Guidance, the off-site impacts were determined for each regulated substance utilized at the Pinova Plant.   The Pinova has one toxic chemical, Trimethylchlorosilane, and one flammable chemical, hydrogen that are in considered covered processes under the RMP rule.  The facility examined worst-case a

nd alternative case scenarios for both chemicals using the EPA's RMP*COMP program.  The chemical or substance that resulted in the most significant off-site impacts under the worst-case release scenario was Trimethylchlorosilane.  A hydrogen worst-case release scenario was also reported but its impacts were less than the toxic chemical. 



The worst-case scenario for Trimethylchlorosilane is the instantaneous release of a 725-pound cylinder.  The impact of such a release using the EPA specified meteorological conditions would result in a vapor cloud that would reach off-site receptors.  No active or passive mitigation efforts were considered for the scenario.  



Alternative Case Scenarios:



The alternate case scenario for Trimethylchlorosilane involves the release of half the contents of a cylinder (360 pounds).  More typical meteorological conditions for the Brunswick area were used such as those used by the alternative case guidance specified by EPA.  Such a release would result in minimal off-site impacts, just beyond the Pinova fence line.   



The alternate case scenario for Hydrogen  was a vapor cloud explosion that was released over 10 minutes at a release rate of 1240 pounds per minute considering alternative case meteorological conditions as specified by EPA.  Such a release would result in minimal off-site impacts, just beyond the Pinova fence line.   



Accident Prevention Program:



Each of the processes, which uses one or more of the regulated substances, is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and has a complete process safety management system in place.  This includes the use of process hazard analyses to identify and address potential hazards, management of change to control modifications, mechanical integrity procedures for minimizing mechanical failures, detailed operating procedures for process control, operator training for the personnel involved in the process and contractor safety assessments to

closely monitor activities by non-Pinova personnel.



Five Year Accident History:



In the past five years, the Pinova Plant has not had any accidental releases of hydrogen or trimethylchlorosilane that have resulted in on-site injuries or any off-site impacts.



Emergency Response Program:



The Pinova Plant has an emergency response program in place to minimize on-site, as well as off-site, impacts from the release of any of the regulated substances or any chemical utilized in the plant processes.



While significant efforts are practiced to prevent all releases, Pinova is cognizant of the fact that they can and do occur.  To prepare to respond to a release, the plant has a very detailed emergency response program in place.  The key elements of this emergency response program are:



-Written emergency response plans that provide a written step by step procedure for responding to the various types of emergency situations that may arise (fire, spills, hurricanes, etc).



-Emergency Response Contractors that provide twenty four hour, seven day a week response to spill or releases. Fire response is conducted at the incipient level by plant employees and at the structural level by the Brunswick Fire Department whose response time to the site is approximately 5 minutes.  



-All of the emergency response activities are and will continue to be coordinated with the various local agencies.
